citation.article-title: Flexibacter japonensis sp. nov., a new species that produces a novel inhibitor of human leukocyte elastase isolated from soil

p.s: Description of Flexibacter japonensis sp. nov.
Flexibacter japonensis (ja. po. nen’sis. M. L. adj. japonen- sis, referring to Japan, source of the soil from which the organism was isolated)
The cells are Gram- negative, long, slender rods or sometimes filaments, motile by gliding.
Colonies are translucent, orange yellow, flat with irregular edges on nutrient agar.
No growth occurs under anaerobic condition on nutrient agar.
Growth occurs at temperatures ranging from 17° to 44°C.

Positive for catalase, oxidase, nitrate reduction; hydrolysis of gelatin, esculin, and DNA; growth in the presence of 2.0% NaCl; acid production from D-glucose, D-xylose, D- galactose, sucrose, lactose, and maltose; and utilization of glycerol, D-xylose, adonitol, D-fructose, rhamnose, salicin, and inulin.

Negative for the Voges-Proskauer reaction; hydrolysis of casein, chitin and starch; acid production from D-fructose, D-mannitol, D-sorbitol, inositol, and salicin; and utilization of D-mannitol, gentibiose, and D-turanose.
MK-7 is the major menaquinone, and MK-6 is minor menaquinone.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of strain 758 DNA is 49.8 mol % (as determined by high-performance liquid chromatography).
The type strain of Flexibacter japonensis is strain 758.
The type strain has the characteristics described above.
The type strain has been deposited at the Japan Collection of Microorganisms as JCM9735.
